clinical_study.brief_title: Interscalene Brachial Plexus Block Washout to Reverse Inadvertent Phrenic Nerve Blockade
clinical_study.official_title: Interscalene Brachial Plexus Block Washout to Reverse Inadvertent Phrenic Nerve Blockade

brief_summary.textblock:
One of the most frequently performed peripheral nerve blocks (the injection of local anesthetic near nerves to block sensation/ movement to a specific part of the body) is the interscalene brachial plexus block for upper extremity surgeries. This type of block can unmask underlying respiratory issues such as shortness of breath due to a well-known and typically insignificant side effect of temporary diaphragmatic paralysis.
The nerve block may be able to use saline solution to wash out the local anesthetic and potentially reverse this respiratory side effect. Specifically, the goal of this study is to determine if the injection of saline through the nerve block catheter reverses blockade of the phrenic nerve supplying the diaphragm, without affecting the ability of the nerve block to provide pain control after surgery.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 15 minutes (5 minutes each for a total of 3 assessments)
primary_outcome.description: Diaphragmatic excursion will be assessed via ultrasound before nerve block is placed, after surgery, and while receiving either the placebo or treatment.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 3 minutes (1 minute each for a total of 3 assessments)
primary_outcome.description: Pain scores will be assessed before nerve block is placed, after surgery, while receiving either the placebo or treatment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Brachial plexus sensory and motor exam
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6 minutes (2 minutes each for a total of 3 assessments)
secondary_outcome.description: Secondary end points include brachial plexus sensory and motor exam changes, which will be assessed before nerve block is placed, after surgery, and while receiving either the placebo or treatment.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 3 minutes (1 minute each for a total of 3 assessments)
secondary_outcome.description: Incentive Spirometry volume will be collected before nerve block is placed, after surgery, and while receiving either the placebo or treatment. An incentive spirometer is a non-invasive device that measures how deeply you can inhale.

clinical_study.condition: Phrenic Nerve Palsy on the Left
Phrenic Nerve Palsy on the Right

arm_group.description: This control group will have no normal saline injected into their nerve catheter (no intervention). This group will have the following measured/ assessed after 10 minutes: incentive spirometry volume, bilateral diaphragmatic excursion via ultrasonography, pain scores (using the Numeric Rating Scale), and brachial plexus motor and sensory exams. Investigators will be blinded to whether the patient is in the intervention or treatment group.

This group will have 30ml normal saline injected into their nerve catheter. The treatment group will have the following measured/ assessed after 10 minutes: incentive spirometry volume, bilateral diaphragmatic excursion via ultrasonography, pain scores (using the Numeric Rating Scale), and brachial plexus motor and sensory exams. Investigators will be blinded to whether the patient is in the intervention or treatment group.

intervention.intervention_name: Normal saline injected via interscalene nerve catheter
intervention.description: With the catheter covered, treatment group patients will receive a normal saline (NS) bolus regimen (30cc 0.9% NS) via their interscalene nerve block catheter.
With the catheter covered, placebo group patients will go through the same steps as the treatment group, but no solution will be injected into the interscalene nerve block catheter.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- All adult patients (18 years and over) scheduled for surgery requiring a continuous interscalene brachial plexus nerve block catheter as part of their anesthetic care.
Exclusion criteria:
- Concomitant life-threatening injuries and other concomitant injuries causing significant pain
- Pregnant
- Any condition impairing patient's ability to consent to participation in study, and an existing condition contraindicating a nerve block, i.e. nerve injury, existing bleeding disorder, infection in the vicinity of the block, and patient refusal.
